awd_titl_txt: MAKER: Making Opportunities for Baltimore Inner City Youth in a 3D Print Shop
awd_abstract_narration:
Real-world problem solving through Making is a new and popular way to engage youth in STEM education. Since it is often difficult to infuse Maker curriculum into students' schedules, this frequently occurs in after-school programs. Unfortunately, not all youth are able to participate in after-school activities due to financial pressures and may instead take jobs in non-technical fields such as food service or retail. These non-technical jobs take time away from Making, designing, and tinkering, which can leave them behind their peers who are honing skills for a technical career path. We propose to create a living laboratory "print shop" at the Digital Harbor Foundation (DHF) Tech Center in Baltimore to study the impact of Maker employment with inner city youth. Research will be conducted to understand how their experiences in the print shop maintain their engagement with STEM. The result of the project will be a new model to keep underserved youth on a pathway towards a STEM career.
 
While integrating Making in formal and informal learning is an active research topic, little is known about how to support Making in youth employment. This research will answer questions crucial to deepening youth engagement in Making such as: 1) How do youths' perceptions of STEM careers and STEM education change with a Maker job? 2) How does real-world client work impact youths' interest in Making and their "design thinking"? 3) What impact does a youth-run 3D print shop have in the local community? 4) What are the generalizable recommendations for designing and teaching digital fabrication software to individuals with diverse skills? 
We will answer these questions by conducting interviews, observations, and workshops, with DHF youth, support staff, and the print shop's customers. All software, training tools, and supporting technology will be evaluated through longitudinal deployments in the print shop. We will track youth's engagement in the print shop and measure how their attitudes towards technical employment, STEM fields, and Making change through the research. We will share our experiences, tools, training materials, and strategies to continue to diversify Making and provide novel employment opportunities with the Maker and academic community.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
While many formal and informal learning and training programs strive to equip the next generation of workers with the technical and social skills necessary to succeed in the future workplace, it is still unclear what specific communication and coordination skills are needed to effectively navigate increasingly technology-rich work settings. Furthermore, we need to better understand how young employees navigate ever-evolving workplace technologies, what challenges they face when doing so, and how they can be prepared better to face them. Furthermore, given the need to broaden participation in STEM fields, more research needs to investigate how to use emerging rapid prototyping and fabrication technologies, such as 3D printing, 3D scanning, and laser cutting, to create exciting opportunities for community engagement and the inclusion of diverse stakeholders in technology design and development.   

To study these questions, we established a living laboratory print shop at the Digital Harbor Foundation (DHF) in Baltimore City. Over three years, the print shop provided maker employment experiences to youth employees from diverse backgrounds across multiple cohorts. Printshop employees worked on several hundred jobs during this time, manufacturing thousands of unique items using laser cutting, 3D printing, 3D scanning, and design work. Using interviews, focus groups, observations, and participatory design sessions, we studied the impact of the work experience on youth and investigated their attitudes towards different communication and coordination tools and factors that contributed to their successful or unsuccessful appropriation. Furthermore, we studied the community-engaged aspects of having the print shop as a resource in Baltimore City, both concerning how it impacted other youth programs at DHF and the collaboration and innovation possibilities that it enabled more broadly. 

Our findings show that working in the printshop positively impacted the youth's technical and social skills, attitudes towards STEM, and career aspirations. These impacts also improved communication and teamwork skills, patience when dealing with others, an increased emphasis on paying attention to details, and improved time and financial management skills. Additionally, despite their prior experience with digital communication tools outside of the workplace, the youth needed further support and training for effectively adopting and using various workplace communication tools and protocols. Furthermore, we found that being exposed to the print shop positively impacted other youth attending DHF?s learning programs and encouraged them to consider STEM careers and entrepreneurial goals. Finally, we successfully leveraged the print shop as a community resource to enable several inclusive initiatives to serve the broader Baltimore City community and involve youth employees in socially engaged activities. These projects included designing customized assistive technologies for adults with disabilities, creating an accessible audio playback interface for children with cognitive disabilities, and making a distributed multimodal activities book for children with or without disabilities that combined storytelling with tangible and audio elements.

 


Last Modified: 10/12/2021
Modified by: Foad Hamidi
